key_1.snippet: Aetna Inc., one of the nation's biggest health insurers, said yesterday that its U.S. Healthcare health plans would eliminate coverage for advanced fertility treatments, including in vitro fertilization, on April 1.     The company said that women...
key_1.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc., one of the nation's biggest health insurers, said yesterday that its U.S. Healthcare health plans would eliminate coverage for advanced fertility treatments, including in vitro fertilization, on April 1. The company said that women who had fertility problems had been joining the U.S. Healthcare plans because they knew the advanced treatments were available. Aetna has recently been under pressure from Wall Street investors to reduce costs and increase profits.
key_1.abstract: US Healthcare unit of Aetna Inc will eliminate coverage for advanced fertility treatments, including in vitro fertilization; says women were joining its plans because they knew the advanced treatments were available; Aetna has been under pressure from Wall Street investors to reduce costs and increase profits; decision is criticized by doctors and advocates of infertility patients, who say many couples are already struggling to cover costs of such treatments out of their own pockets; photo (M)

headline.main: AETNA IS REDUCING FERTILITY BENEFITS

key_1.snippet: Dr. Barbara A. DeBuono said yesterday that she would step down as the New York State Commissioner of Health, a position she has held for nearly four years in a time of great change in the state's health care system.    Dr. DeBuono, 43, will become...
key_1.lead_paragraph: Dr. Barbara A. DeBuono said yesterday that she would step down as the New York State Commissioner of Health, a position she has held for nearly four years in a time of great change in the state's health care system. Dr. DeBuono, 43, will become what amounts to the No. 3 executive at New York Presbyterian Healthcare System, the new conglomeration of 28 hospitals, nursing homes and other health care agencies assembled around one of the nation's most prestigious medical institutions, the New York and Presbyterian Hospital.
key_1.abstract: Dr Barbara A DeBuono says she will step down as New York State Commissioner of Health, position she has held for nearly four years in time of great change in state's health care system; DeBuono will become what amounts to No 3 executive at New York Presbyterian Healthcare System, new conglomeration of 28 hospitals, nursing homes and other health care agencies assembled around one of nation's most prestigious medical institutions, New York and Presbyterian Hospital; she will begin her new job on Nov 1 (M)

headline.main: Health Commissioner Is Leaving

key_4.snippet: A total cholesterol test measures all the cholesterol in your blood. Cholesterol is a soft, wax-like substance found in all parts of the body. Your body needs a little bit of cholesterol to work properly. But too much cholesterol can clog your art...
key_4.lead_paragraph: A total cholesterol test measures all the cholesterol in your blood. Cholesterol is a soft, wax-like substance found in all parts of the body. Your body needs a little bit of cholesterol to work properly. But too much cholesterol can clog your arteries and lead to heart disease. Some cholesterol is considered "good" and some is considered "bad." Different blood tests are needed to individually measure each type of cholesterol. See also: HDL test (high density lipoprotein, or "good" cholesterol) High blood cholesterol and triglycerides LDL test (low density lipoprotein, or "bad" cholesterol) Lipid profile

headline.main: Cholesterol Test

key_5.snippet: Health care.. for. women, long one of the major issues of the-women's movement, was discussed and dissected here at a day-long conference that turned out-to be more of a gripe session than anything else. Called "Psychological Perspectives in Women...
key_5.lead_paragraph: Health care.. for. women, long one of the major issues of the-women's movement, was discussed and dissected here at a day-long conference that turned out-to be more of a gripe session than anything else. Called "Psychological Perspectives in Women's Medicine: - Telling- It the Way It Feels," it was a get-together to discuss such things as unnecessary surgery, ondescension of doctors to women patients, depression as a feminist issue, and medical consumerism.
key_5.abstract: Consultation Center for Women and Eastern Women's Center, NYC, co-sponsor symposium called Psychological Perspectives in Women's Med: Telling It the Way It Feels; conf is discussion of women's reactions to health care they receive; features guest panel of psychologists, gynecologists, science writers, natural health experts and a nurse-midwife; author Barbara Seaman, clinical psychologist Freyda Zell and Dr Edward Stim comment; illus (M)

headline.main: Women and Their Doctors--The Sad and Cautionary Tales; Describes Hostility

key_5.snippet: To the growing numbers of medical experts who preach evidence-based medicine -- the discipline that insists on proof that time-honored medical practices and procedures are actually effective -- there is no more inviting target than the annual phys...
key_5.lead_paragraph: To the growing numbers of medical experts who preach evidence-based medicine -- the discipline that insists on proof that time-honored medical practices and procedures are actually effective -- there is no more inviting target than the annual physical. Checkups for people with no medical complaint remain the single most common reason for visiting a doctor, according to surveys by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In 2000, they accounted for about 64 million office visits, out of 823.5 million visits over all. At $120 to $150 per visit (and $2,000 or so for the gold-plated ''executive physical'' that many companies offer to top executives), that adds up to more than $7 billion a year.
key_5.abstract: Annual medical checkups remain most common reason people visit their doctor, despite series of reports beginning in 1989 that find little support for symptomless physicals; committee sponsored by federal Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality finds routine physicals can lead to false alarms and unnecessary, and sometimes risky, follow-up tests; doctors admit they continue to do annual physicals for variety of reasons, including routine familiarity and simply keeping their patients happy, but they themselves question tangible benefit in yearly ritual; annual checkup does help establish doctor-patient relationship, giving people sense of confidence they have someone to help if symptoms do arise; story of Dr John K Min exemplifies dilemma doctors face; photos (M)

headline.main: Annual Physical Checkup May Be an Empty Ritual

keywords.name: organizations

headline.print_headline: Two U.S. States to Quarantine Health Workers Returning From Ebola Zones

key_6.snippet: To the growing numbers of medical experts who preach evidence-based medicine -- the discipline that insists on proof that time-honored medical practices and procedures are actually effective -- there is no more inviting target than the annual phys...
key_6.lead_paragraph: To the growing numbers of medical experts who preach evidence-based medicine -- the discipline that insists on proof that time-honored medical practices and procedures are actually effective -- there is no more inviting target than the annual physical. Checkups for people with no medical complaint remain the single most common reason for visiting a doctor, according to surveys by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In 2000, they accounted for about 64 million office visits, out of 823.5 million visits over all. At $120 to $150 per visit (and $2,000 or so for the gold-plated ''executive physical'' that many companies offer to top executives), that adds up to more than $7 billion a year.
key_6.abstract: Annual medical checkups remain most common reason people visit their doctor, despite series of reports beginning in 1989 that find little support for symptomless physicals; committee sponsored by federal Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality finds routine physicals can lead to false alarms and unnecessary, and sometimes risky, follow-up tests; doctors admit they continue to do annual physicals for variety of reasons, including routine familiarity and simply keeping their patients happy, but they themselves question tangible benefit in yearly ritual; annual checkup does help establish doctor-patient relationship, giving people sense of confidence they have someone to help if symptoms do arise; story of Dr John K Min exemplifies dilemma doctors face; photos (M)

headline.main: Annual Physical Checkup May Be an Empty Ritual

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY

key_6.snippet: The New York State Catholic Conference produced a blistering 9-minute YouTube video that assails a proposal by the Spitzer administration to revise the state abortion law....
key_6.lead_paragraph: The New York State Catholic Conference has produced a blistering nine-minute YouTube video that assails a proposal by the Spitzer administration to update abortion laws. The creation of the video, which argues that the State Senate offers the best hope of defeating the measure, suggests that abortion could emerge as a hot issue in the state elections this fall. Republicans will try to hold on to their thin margin in the Senate, their last bastion of power in Albany, but strong turnout for the presidential election could aid Democratic efforts to take control of the entire Legislature for the first time in decades.
key_6.abstract: The New York State Catholic Conference produced a blistering 9-minute YouTube video that assails a proposal by the Spitzer administration to revise the state abortion law.

headline.main: Video Intensifies Abortion Debate in Albany

key_6.snippet: Women's place in professional schools: more is merrier....
key_6.lead_paragraph: Lena Kagan, the first female dean of Harvard Law School, had an epiphany in the women's bathroom at a conference hall in Cambridge, Mass., last year. There, neatly stacked in a basket, was a supply of free tampons. ''It's such a small thing, but it says a lot about whether a place cares about its women,'' she says. A few months later, every women's room at Harvard Law had a supply. Change is taking many forms these days at the nation's professional schools. Business students network at potluck dinners. Medical schools incorporate more materials on women's health. At law schools, the Socratic method has come under attack, its dominance diluted by approaches thought to be more woman-friendly. The changes reflect the schools' responses to increased numbers of female students.
key_6.abstract: Yilu Zhao article on how nation's law, business and medical schools are changing in ways that reflect increased numbers of female students; photo (special section, Education Life) (L)

headline.main: Beyond 'Sweetie'

key_6.snippet: The Hartford nursing home where 10 residents died in a fire yesterday morning caters to more than just the elderly, having filled its wards in recent years in part by admitting relatively younger people who have schizophrenia, AIDS and other illne...
key_6.lead_paragraph: The Hartford nursing home where 10 residents died in a fire yesterday morning caters to more than just the elderly, having filled its wards in recent years in part by admitting relatively younger people who have schizophrenia, AIDS and other illnesses. The population at the 150-bed home, Greenwood Health Center, reflects a growing willingness of nursing home owners across the nation to cast a wider net for residents in order to confront tough fiscal times and new competition.

headline.main: Residents, Increasingly, Are Younger And Troubled
headline.kicker: FATAL NURSING HOME FIRE: THE HOME

key_8.lead_paragraph: The cost of emergency room care for the mentally ill shows no sign of ebbing, but a North Carolina hospital is experimenting to save money and better help patients.
key_8.abstract: WakeMed Health and Hospitals in Raleigh, NC, has rolled out pilot program for aiding mentally ill patients without admitting them to emergency rooms, drawing attention of troubled hospitals nationwide; cost of emergency room care for the mentally ill, which is often wasteful and unhelpful, is expected to balloon to $38.5 billion in 2014, even as other health care costs decline.

headline.main: E.R. Costs for Mentally Ill Soar, and Hospitals Seek Better Way
headline.print_headline: E.R. Costs for Mentally Ill Soar, and Hospitals Seek Better Way

key_8.snippet: A NEW KIND of medical center -- where comprehensive care is provided to women, mostly    by    women -- is gaining popularity in Connecticut. One such center operates in Cheshire; another opened this fall in Groton, and a third is scheduled to sta...
key_8.lead_paragraph: A NEW KIND of medical center -- where comprehensive care is provided to women, mostly by women -- is gaining popularity in Connecticut. One such center operates in Cheshire; another opened this fall in Groton, and a third is scheduled to start next year in Vernon. "I think it's a coming trend," said Dr. Carolyn D'Avanzo, a professor of nursing at the University of Connecticut in Storrs. "It's giving women what they want, and it's meeting their needs."

headline.main: Patients Trust Woman-to-Woman Care

key_8.lead_paragraph: An effort by the United Nations to draw attention to the fact that the global population is now or soon will be 7 billion sowed confusion on Monday, as some news organizations, anxious to put a human face on the estimate, searched the globe for a newborn to anoint the seven billionth person, conflating a projection with an exact count.

key_8.snippet: Most American families can thank the woman of the house for nearly all of the pay gains they have received over the last year.    While men's wages have failed to keep up with even the low rate of inflation, women's earnings have continued to grow...
key_8.lead_paragraph: Most American families can thank the woman of the house for nearly all of the pay gains they have received over the last year. While men's wages have failed to keep up with even the low rate of inflation, women's earnings have continued to grow, giving an important lift to many families and helping sustain consumer spending.
key_8.abstract: Women's earnings have continued to grow over last year, giving important lift to many families, helping to sustain consumer spending and closing gap between men's and women's wages to narrowest on record; men's wages have failed to keep up with even low rate of inflation; women's pay still lags behind men's in every sector of economy; Bureau of Labor Statistics shows women made 77.5 percent of what men did last year; median full-time female worker received 5 percent raise last year, while median pay for men rose only 1.3 percent; pay gap in US is slightly larger than in most other leading economies according to Organization for Economic Cooperation; photo; graph compares wage gender gap (L)

headline.main: Gap Between Pay Of Men and Women Smallest on Record
